Title: Organization of the amygdalopetal projections from modality-specific cortical association areas in the monkey

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The major portion of the subcortical amygdala consists of three nuclei which occupy the base of this complex. From lateral to medial they are the lateral, basal, and basal accessory nuclei. ...These three nuclei have been further subdivided in the rhesus monkey by Jimenez-Castellanos ('49) and Mikami ('52), but because these subdivisions are not readily apparent in normal material, they will not be referred to here." (p. 517)

"The major portion of the subcortical amygdala consists of three nuclei which occupy the base of this complex. From lateral to medial they are the lateral, basal, and basal accessory nuclei. ...These three nuclei have been further subdivided in the rhesus monkey by Jimenez-Castellanos ('49) and Mikami ('52), but because these subdivisions are not readily apparent in normal material, they will not be referred to here." (p. 517)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: It seems that the parcellation of the amygdaloid complex corresponds mainly to that of J49, because (i) J49 has been already cited for three nuclei of the amygdala (see the citation) and (ii) the nuclei have approximately the same location.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The occipital lobe, OC &OB &OA. The entire occipital lobe was removed in one animal (Fig. 7), including all of Bonin and Bailey's ('47) cytoarchitectural areas OC, OB, and OA except that part of OA that has been designated TEO, as described below. ...The occipitotemporal junction, TEO. Bailey et al. ('50 defined the transitional zone between the occipital and temporal lobes of the chimpanzee as a distinct cytoarchitectural division, area PH, though they had not identified it in the rhesus monkey (Bonin and Bailey, '47), where this zone was included within OA." (p. 521) "The designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47) were adopted because they provide a complete classification of the neocortex of Macaca mulatta, the species used in the present experiment." (p. 521, description of figure 7)

"The occipital lobe, OC &OB &OA. The entire occipital lobe was removed in one animal (Fig. 7), including all of Bonin and Bailey's ('47) cytoarchitectural areas OC, OB, and OA except that part of OA that has been designated TEO, as described below. ...The occipitotemporal junction, TEO. Bailey et al. ('50 defined the transitional zone between the occipital and temporal lobes of the chimpanzee as a distinct cytoarchitectural division, area PH, though they had not identified it in the rhesus monkey (Bonin and Bailey, '47), where this zone was included within OA." (p. 521) "The designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47) were adopted because they provide a complete classification of the neocortex of Macaca mulatta, the species used in the present experiment." (p. 521, description of figure 7)

"The occipital lobe, OC &OB &OA. The entire occipital lobe was removed in one animal (Fig. 7), including all of Bonin and Bailey's ('47) cytoarchitectural areas OC, OB, and OA except that part of OA that has been designated TEO, as described below. ...The occipitotemporal junction, TEO. Bailey et al. ('50 defined the transitional zone between the occipital and temporal lobes of the chimpanzee as a distinct cytoarchitectural division, area PH, though they had not identified it in the rhesus monkey (Bonin and Bailey, '47), where this zone was included within OA." (p. 521) "The designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47) were adopted because they provide a complete classification of the neocortex of Macaca mulatta, the species used in the present experiment." (p. 521, description of figure 7)

Bailey et al. ('50 defined the transitional zone between the occipital and temporal lobes of the chimpanzee as a distinct cytoarchitectural division, area PH, though they had not identified it in the rhesus monkey (Bonin and Bailey, '47), where this zone was included within OA." (p. 521) "The designations of Bonin and Bailey ('47) were adopted because they provide a complete classification of the neocortex of Macaca mulatta, the species used in the present experiment." (p. 521, description of figure 7)
